text:
Freddo is next in line for a huge price hike – and everyone's losing the plot In 2000, Freddo bars cost just 10p Share Freddo bars are going up (Photo: Cadbury) Share Get money   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The world is on fire. Truly it is. And, right now, it seems like Mondalez International is the one setting it ablaze. 
First, the company cut the weight of Toblerone – crucially, without reducing the price. People were furious. 
And now another adored confectionery staple is going to be blighted by the relentless hand of the corporation: the manufacturer is raising the price of our chocolate frogs. Yes, our beloved Freddo treats are going up in price. Again. Mondelez, then operating as Kraft, took over Cadbury in 2010 (Photo: Mondelez International / PA) 
It's expected that Cadbury Freddo bars will cost you 30p from spring this year. That's a 20 per cent increase from the already extortionate sum of 25p. 
Let's not forget that Freddos have also shrunk in weight over the years. They're now just 12g. This is a disgrace, quite frankly 
A Mondelez spokesperson declined to discuss specific brands, but confirmed to the Guardian that 2017 would see "selective" price increases across its range. 
The confectionery giant reported profits of £450m in its last financial quarter. 
"Increasing prices is always a last resort, but to ensure we can keep people’s favourite brands on shelf and look after the 4,500 people we employ in the UK, we are having to make some selective price increases across our range," a spokesman for Mondelez said. 
The company bought Cadbury in 2010. It's implemented numerous changes – amplified, it appears, in the wake of Britain's vote to leave the EU. 
Maltesers were downsized after Toblerone. The bags are now 15 per cent lighter. Freddo is next. This graph shows the rapid ascent of Freddo costs Freddo price increase (Photo: Twitter / @vouchercloud) 
Mondelez has previously cited Brexit as one of the reasons for its price hikes: “It is well reported that food and drink manufacturers have been experiencing increasing commodity costs for some time which, coupled with recent foreign exchange pressures, are making food products more expensive to make. 
"For example, the price of cocoa, which we import into the UK, is up by over 50 per cent since 2013." 
It's true to say that chocolate production is costing makers more. 
A 'milk chocolate index' created by analysts at Mintec last November showed the combined price of particular ingredients – cocoa butter, cocoa powder, whey, sugar, and whole milk powder – is up almost 30 per cent year-on-year, The Independent writes. Read More
